title: 106_s1891
content: The "Literacy Involves Families Together Act" authorizes $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 for improving basic programs operated by local educational agencies. The "Literacy Involves Families Together Act" authorizes $500,000,000 for improving basic programs operated by local educational agencies by amending the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include encouraging family literacy services for students with parents lacking a high school diploma or literacy skills. SEC. 4. EVEN START FAMILY LITERACY PROGRAMS. The Even Start Family Literacy Program is amended to include a reservation for migrant programs, outlying areas, and Indian tribes. The Secretary must coordinate programs for American Indians under this amendment. The Secretary must coordinate family literacy programs for American Indians to avoid duplication and promote high-quality programs. The reservation for federal activities allows the Secretary to reserve funds for evaluation, technical assistance, and program improvement. The Secretary reserves funds for evaluation, technical assistance, and program improvement under section 1209. Additionally, excess amounts appropriated for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 will be used for research under section 1211(b). The Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow states to use funds for family literacy services, specifically to improve the quality of services provided under Even Start programs. States can allocate a portion of funds received to assist eligible entities in this endeavor. Under this part, states can use funds to improve family literacy services without decreasing the level of activities and services provided to program participants. Priority should be given to low-quality programs, and technical assistance and training will be provided through grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements with experienced entities. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to include the use of instructional programs based on scientifically based reading research for children and adults. Eligible participants include children 8 years of age or older in Even Start programs collaborating with other programs under part A. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to include instructional programs based on reading research for children and adults. Even Start programs can now include children 8 years or older. Subgrants are awarded based on program progress and evaluation. Section 1211 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include scientifically-based research on family literacy. The National Institute for Literacy conducts scientifically-based research on family literacy to improve adult literacy skills and support parents in their children's literacy development. The National Institute for Literacy will conduct research on literacy development in children through an entity with expertise in longitudinal studies and interventions for reading difficulties. SEC. 5 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include encouraging family literacy services for migratory children. SEC. 6 provides definitions. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include family literacy services, defined as voluntary services that promote interactive literacy activities between parents and children, and provide training for parents to be primary teachers and partners in their children's education. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include family literacy services, promoting interactive literacy activities between parents and children, and providing parent literacy training for economic self-sufficiency and age-appropriate education for children's success in school and life. Conforming amendments are made to Even Start family literacy programs and reading and literacy grants. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include family literacy services, promoting interactive literacy activities between parents and children, and providing parent literacy training for economic self-sufficiency and age-appropriate education for children's success in school and life. Conforming amendments are made to Even Start family literacy programs and reading and literacy grants. Paragraphs (3) through (5) are redesignated as paragraphs (2) through (4), respectively. SEC. 7. INDIAN EDUCATION. Amendment to the Early Childhood Development Program under the Indian Education Act includes adding family literacy services and programs. The Early Childhood Development Program under the Indian Education Act is amended to include family literacy programs. Family literacy programs must be coordinated to avoid duplication and promote quality services for American Indian children. Definitions are updated to align with the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
